You are an expert in causal inference. The following question is not a typical commonsense query, but rather a meticulously designed question created by a professor specializing in causal inference, intended to assess the students' mastery of the course content.
Imagine a self-contained, hypothetical world with only the following conditions, and without any unmentioned factors or causal relationships: Husband has a direct effect on wife and alarm clock. Wife has a direct effect on alarm clock. The overall probability of alarm set by husband is 18%. The probability of alarm not set by husband and ringing alarm is 56%. The probability of alarm set by husband and ringing alarm is 3%. Is the chance of ringing alarm smaller when observing alarm set by husband?
Start your answer with 'Yes' or 'No', followed by additional reasoning or evidence to support your explanation.
action.label: context

action.content:
No
The probability of the alarm set by the husband and ringing is 3%. The probability of the alarm not set by the husband and ringing is 56%. The probability of the alarm set by the husband is 18%. The probability of the alarm not set by the husband is 82%. The probability of the alarm ringing is the sum of the probability of the alarm set by the husband and ringing (3%) and the probability of the alarm not set by the husband and ringing (56%). This is 59%. The probability of the alarm set by the husband and not ringing is 15% (18% - 3%). The probability of the alarm not set by the husband and not ringing is 27% (82% - 55%). The probability of the alarm not set by the husband is 82%. The probability of the alarm set by the husband is 18%. The probability of the alarm not set by the husband and not ringing is 27%.
